text: This letter is from Paul, chosen by the will of God to be an apostle of Christ Jesus, and from our brother Sosthenes.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am writing to God’s church in Corinth, to you who have been called by God to be his own holy people. He made you holy by means of Christ Jesus, just as he did for all people everywhere who call on the name of our Lord Jesus Christ, their Lord and ours.
speaker: Narrator

text: May God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ give you grace and peace.
speaker: Narrator

text: I always thank my God for you and for the gracious gifts he has given you, now that you belong to Christ Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: Through him, God has enriched your church in every way—with all of your eloquent words and all of your knowledge.
speaker: Narrator

text: This confirms that what I told you about Christ is true.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now you have every spiritual gift you need as you eagerly wait for the return of our Lord Jesus Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will keep you strong to the end so that you will be free from all blame on the day when our Lord Jesus Christ returns.
speaker: Narrator

text: God will do this, for he is faithful to do what he says, and he has invited you into partnership with his Son, Jesus Christ our Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: I appeal to you, dear brothers and sisters, by the authority of our Lord Jesus Christ, to live in harmony with each other. Let there be no divisions in the church. Rather, be of one mind, united in thought and purpose.
speaker: Narrator

text: For some members of Chloe’s household have told me about your quarrels, my dear brothers and sisters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some of you are saying, “I am a follower of Paul.” Others are saying, “I follow Apollos,” or “I follow Peter,” or “I follow only Christ.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Has Christ been divided into factions? Was I, Paul, crucified for you? Were any of you baptized in the name of Paul? Of course not!
speaker: Narrator

text: I thank God that I did not baptize any of you except Crispus and Gaius,
speaker: Narrator

text: for now no one can say they were baptized in my name.
speaker: Narrator

text: (Oh yes, I also baptized the household of Stephanas, but I don’t remember baptizing anyone else.)
speaker: Narrator

text: For Christ didn’t send me to baptize, but to preach the Good News—and not with clever speech, for fear that the cross of Christ would lose its power.
speaker: Narrator

text: The message of the cross is foolish to those who are headed for destruction! But we who are being saved know it is the very power of God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As the Scriptures say,
“I will destroy the wisdom of the wise
    and discard the intelligence of the intelligent.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So where does this leave the philosophers, the scholars, and the world’s brilliant debaters? God has made the wisdom of this world look foolish.
speaker: Narrator

text: Since God in his wisdom saw to it that the world would never know him through human wisdom, he has used our foolish preaching to save those who believe.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is foolish to the Jews, who ask for signs from heaven. And it is foolish to the Greeks, who seek human wisdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: So when we preach that Christ was crucified, the Jews are offended and the Gentiles say it’s all nonsense.
speaker: Narrator

text: But to those called by God to salvation, both Jews and Gentiles, Christ is the power of God and the wisdom of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: This foolish plan of God is wiser than the wisest of human plans, and God’s weakness is stronger than the greatest of human strength.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember, dear brothers and sisters, that few of you were wise in the world’s eyes or powerful or wealthy when God called you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Instead, God chose things the world considers foolish in order to shame those who think they are wise. And he chose things that are powerless to shame those who are powerful.
speaker: Narrator

text: God chose things despised by the world, things counted as nothing at all, and used them to bring to nothing what the world considers important.
speaker: Narrator

text: As a result, no one can ever boast in the presence of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: God has united you with Christ Jesus. For our benefit God made him to be wisdom itself. Christ made us right with God; he made us pure and holy, and he freed us from sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, as the Scriptures say, “If you want to boast, boast only about the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When I first came to you, dear brothers and sisters, I didn’t use lofty words and impressive wisdom to tell you God’s secret plan.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I decided that while I was with you I would forget everything except Jesus Christ, the one who was crucified.
speaker: Narrator

text: I came to you in weakness—timid and trembling.
speaker: Narrator

text: And my message and my preaching were very plain. Rather than using clever and persuasive speeches, I relied only on the power of the Holy Spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text: I did this so you would trust not in human wisdom but in the power of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet when I am among mature believers, I do speak with words of wisdom, but not the kind of wisdom that belongs to this world or to the rulers of this world, who are soon forgotten.
speaker: Narrator

text: No, the wisdom we speak of is the mystery of God—his plan that was previously hidden, even though he made it for our ultimate glory before the world began.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the rulers of this world have not understood it; if they had, they would not have crucified our glorious Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
That is what the Scriptures mean when they say, 
“No eye has seen, no ear has heard,
    and no mind has imagined
what God has prepared
    for those who love him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But it was to us that God revealed these things by his Spirit. For his Spirit searches out everything and shows us God’s deep secrets.
speaker: Narrator

text: No one can know a person’s thoughts except that person’s own spirit, and no one can know God’s thoughts except God’s own Spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text: And we have received God’s Spirit (not the world’s spirit), so we can know the wonderful things God has freely given us.
speaker: Narrator

text: When we tell you these things, we do not use words that come from human wisdom. Instead, we speak words given to us by the Spirit, using the Spirit’s words to explain spiritual truths.
speaker: Narrator

text: But people who aren’t spiritual can’t receive these truths from God’s Spirit. It all sounds foolish to them and they can’t understand it, for only those who are spiritual can understand what the Spirit means.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who are spiritual can evaluate all things, but they themselves cannot be evaluated by others.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For,
“Who can know the Lord’s thoughts?
    Who knows enough to teach him?”
But we understand these things, for we have the mind of Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: Dear brothers and sisters, when I was with you I couldn’t talk to you as I would to spiritual people. I had to talk as though you belonged to this world or as though you were infants in Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: I had to feed you with milk, not with solid food, because you weren’t ready for anything stronger. And you still aren’t ready,
speaker: Narrator

text: for you are still controlled by your sinful nature. You are jealous of one another and quarrel with each other. Doesn’t that prove you are controlled by your sinful nature? Aren’t you living like people of the world?
speaker: Narrator

text: When one of you says, “I am a follower of Paul,” and another says, “I follow Apollos,” aren’t you acting just like people of the world?
speaker: Narrator

text: After all, who is Apollos? Who is Paul? We are only God’s servants through whom you believed the Good News. Each of us did the work the Lord gave us.
speaker: Narrator

text: I planted the seed in your hearts, and Apollos watered it, but it was God who made it grow.
speaker: Narrator

text: It’s not important who does the planting, or who does the watering. What’s important is that God makes the seed grow.
speaker: Narrator

text: The one who plants and the one who waters work together with the same purpose. And both will be rewarded for their own hard work.
speaker: Narrator

text: For we are both God’s workers. And you are God’s field. You are God’s building.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because of God’s grace to me, I have laid the foundation like an expert builder. Now others are building on it. But whoever is building on this foundation must be very careful.
speaker: Narrator

text: For no one can lay any foundation other than the one we already have—Jesus Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone who builds on that foundation may use a variety of materials—gold, silver, jewels, wood, hay, or straw.
speaker: Narrator

text: But on the judgment day, fire will reveal what kind of work each builder has done. The fire will show if a person’s work has any value.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the work survives, that builder will receive a reward.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if the work is burned up, the builder will suffer great loss. The builder will be saved, but like someone barely escaping through a wall of flames.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t you realize that all of you together are the temple of God and that the Spirit of God lives in you?
speaker: Narrator

text: God will destroy anyone who destroys this temple. For God’s temple is holy, and you are that temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: Stop deceiving yourselves. If you think you are wise by this world’s standards, you need to become a fool to be truly wise.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the wisdom of this world is foolishness to God. As the Scriptures say,
“He traps the wise
    in the snare of their own cleverness.”
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: So don’t boast about following a particular human leader. For everything belongs to you—
speaker: Narrator

text: whether Paul or Apollos or Peter, or the world, or life and death, or the present and the future. Everything belongs to you,
speaker: Narrator

text: and you belong to Christ, and Christ belongs to God.
speaker: Narrator

text: So look at Apollos and me as mere servants of Christ who have been put in charge of explaining God’s mysteries.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, a person who is put in charge as a manager must be faithful.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for me, it matters very little how I might be evaluated by you or by any human authority. I don’t even trust my own judgment on this point.
speaker: Narrator

text: My conscience is clear, but that doesn’t prove I’m right. It is the Lord himself who will examine me and decide.
speaker: Narrator

text: So don’t make judgments about anyone ahead of time—before the Lord returns. For he will bring our darkest secrets to light and will reveal our private motives. Then God will give to each one whatever praise is due.
speaker: Narrator

text: Dear brothers and sisters, I have used Apollos and myself to illustrate what I’ve been saying. If you pay attention to what I have quoted from the Scriptures, you won’t be proud of one of your leaders at the expense of another.
speaker: Narrator

text: For what gives you the right to make such a judgment? What do you have that God hasn’t given you? And if everything you have is from God, why boast as though it were not a gift?
speaker: Narrator

text: You think you already have everything you need. You think you are already rich. You have begun to reign in God’s kingdom without us! I wish you really were reigning already, for then we would be reigning with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Instead, I sometimes think God has put us apostles on display, like prisoners of war at the end of a victor’s parade, condemned to die. We have become a spectacle to the entire world—to people and angels alike.
speaker: Narrator

text: Our dedication to Christ makes us look like fools, but you claim to be so wise in Christ! We are weak, but you are so powerful! You are honored, but we are ridiculed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even now we go hungry and thirsty, and we don’t have enough clothes to keep warm. We are often beaten and have no home.
speaker: Narrator

text: We work wearily with our own hands to earn our living. We bless those who curse us. We are patient with those who abuse us.
speaker: Narrator

text: We appeal gently when evil things are said about us. Yet we are treated like the world’s garbage, like everybody’s trash—right up to the present moment.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am not writing these things to shame you, but to warn you as my beloved children.
speaker: Narrator

text: For even if you had ten thousand others to teach you about Christ, you have only one spiritual father. For I became your father in Christ Jesus when I preached the Good News to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I urge you to imitate me.
speaker: Narrator

text: That’s why I have sent Timothy, my beloved and faithful child in the Lord. He will remind you of how I follow Christ Jesus, just as I teach in all the churches wherever I go.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some of you have become arrogant, thinking I will not visit you again.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I will come—and soon—if the Lord lets me, and then I’ll find out whether these arrogant people just give pretentious speeches or whether they really have God’s power.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Kingdom of God is not just a lot of talk; it is living by God’s power.
speaker: Narrator

text: Which do you choose? Should I come with a rod to punish you, or should I come with love and a gentle spirit?
speaker: Narrator

text: I can hardly believe the report about the sexual immorality going on among you—something that even pagans don’t do. I am told that a man in your church is living in sin with his stepmother.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are so proud of yourselves, but you should be mourning in sorrow and shame. And you should remove this man from your fellowship.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even though I am not with you in person, I am with you in the Spirit. And as though I were there, I have already passed judgment on this man
speaker: Narrator

text: in the name of the Lord Jesus. You must call a meeting of the church. I will be present with you in spirit, and so will the power of our Lord Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you must throw this man out and hand him over to Satan so that his sinful nature will be destroyed and he himself will be saved on the day the Lord returns.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your boasting about this is terrible. Don’t you realize that this sin is like a little yeast that spreads through the whole batch of dough?
speaker: Narrator

text: Get rid of the old “yeast” by removing this wicked person from among you. Then you will be like a fresh batch of dough made without yeast, which is what you really are. Christ, our Passover Lamb, has been sacrificed for us.
speaker: Narrator

text: So let us celebrate the festival, not with the old bread of wickedness and evil, but with the new bread of sincerity and truth.
speaker: Narrator

text: When I wrote to you before, I told you not to associate with people who indulge in sexual sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I wasn’t talking about unbelievers who indulge in sexual sin, or are greedy, or cheat people, or worship idols. You would have to leave this world to avoid people like that.
speaker: Narrator

text: I meant that you are not to associate with anyone who claims to be a believer yet indulges in sexual sin, or is greedy, or worships idols, or is abusive, or is a drunkard, or cheats people. Don’t even eat with such people.
speaker: Narrator

text: It isn’t my responsibility to judge outsiders, but it certainly is your responsibility to judge those inside the church who are sinning.
speaker: Narrator

text: God will judge those on the outside; but as the Scriptures say, “You must remove the evil person from among you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When one of you has a dispute with another believer, how dare you file a lawsuit and ask a secular court to decide the matter instead of taking it to other believers!
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t you realize that someday we believers will judge the world? And since you are going to judge the world, can’t you decide even these little things among yourselves?
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t you realize that we will judge angels? So you should surely be able to resolve ordinary disputes in this life.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you have legal disputes about such matters, why go to outside judges who are not respected by the church?
speaker: Narrator

text: I am saying this to shame you. Isn’t there anyone in all the church who is wise enough to decide these issues?
speaker: Narrator

text: But instead, one believer sues another—right in front of unbelievers!
speaker: Narrator

text: Even to have such lawsuits with one another is a defeat for you. Why not just accept the injustice and leave it at that? Why not let yourselves be cheated?
speaker: Narrator

text: Instead, you yourselves are the ones who do wrong and cheat even your fellow believers.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t you realize that those who do wrong will not inherit the Kingdom of God? Don’t fool yourselves. Those who indulge in sexual sin, or who worship idols, or commit adultery, or are male prostitutes, or practice homosexuality,
speaker: Narrator

text: or are thieves, or greedy people, or drunkards, or are abusive, or cheat people—none of these will inherit the Kingdom of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some of you were once like that. But you were cleansed; you were made holy; you were made right with God by calling on the name of the Lord Jesus Christ and by the Spirit of our God.
speaker: Narrator

text: You say, “I am allowed to do anything”—but not everything is good for you. And even though “I am allowed to do anything,” I must not become a slave to anything.
speaker: Narrator

text: You say, “Food was made for the stomach, and the stomach for food.” (This is true, though someday God will do away with both of them.) But you can’t say that our bodies were made for sexual immorality. They were made for the Lord, and the Lord cares about our bodies.
speaker: Narrator

text: And God will raise us from the dead by his power, just as he raised our Lord from the dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t you realize that your bodies are actually parts of Christ? Should a man take his body, which is part of Christ, and join it to a prostitute? Never!
speaker: Narrator

text: And don’t you realize that if a man joins himself to a prostitute, he becomes one body with her? For the Scriptures say, “The two are united into one.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the person who is joined to the Lord is one spirit with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Run from sexual sin! No other sin so clearly affects the body as this one does. For sexual immorality is a sin against your own body.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t you realize that your body is the temple of the Holy Spirit, who lives in you and was given to you by God? You do not belong to yourself,
speaker: Narrator

text: for God bought you with a high price. So you must honor God with your body.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now regarding the questions you asked in your letter. Yes, it is good to abstain from sexual relations.
speaker: Narrator

text: But because there is so much sexual immorality, each man should have his own wife, and each woman should have her own husband.
speaker: Narrator

text: The husband should fulfill his wife’s sexual needs, and the wife should fulfill her husband’s needs.
speaker: Narrator

text: The wife gives authority over her body to her husband, and the husband gives authority over his body to his wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not deprive each other of sexual relations, unless you both agree to refrain from sexual intimacy for a limited time so you can give yourselves more completely to prayer. Afterward, you should come together again so that Satan won’t be able to tempt you because of your lack of self-control.
speaker: Narrator

text: I say this as a concession, not as a command.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I wish everyone were single, just as I am. Yet each person has a special gift from God, of one kind or another.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I say to those who aren’t married and to widows—it’s better to stay unmarried, just as I am.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if they can’t control themselves, they should go ahead and marry. It’s better to marry than to burn with lust.
speaker: Narrator

text: But for those who are married, I have a command that comes not from me, but from the Lord. A wife must not leave her husband.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if she does leave him, let her remain single or else be reconciled to him. And the husband must not leave his wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, I will speak to the rest of you, though I do not have a direct command from the Lord. If a fellow believer has a wife who is not a believer and she is willing to continue living with him, he must not leave her.
speaker: Narrator

text: And if a believing woman has a husband who is not a believer and he is willing to continue living with her, she must not leave him.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the believing wife brings holiness to her marriage, and the believing husband brings holiness to his marriage. Otherwise, your children would not be holy, but now they are holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: (But if the husband or wife who isn’t a believer insists on leaving, let them go. In such cases the believing husband or wife is no longer bound to the other, for God has called you to live in peace.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t you wives realize that your husbands might be saved because of you? And don’t you husbands realize that your wives might be saved because of you?
speaker: Narrator

text: Each of you should continue to live in whatever situation the Lord has placed you, and remain as you were when God first called you. This is my rule for all the churches.
speaker: Narrator

text: For instance, a man who was circumcised before he became a believer should not try to reverse it. And the man who was uncircumcised when he became a believer should not be circumcised now.
speaker: Narrator

text: For it makes no difference whether or not a man has been circumcised. The important thing is to keep God’s commandments.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yes, each of you should remain as you were when God called you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Are you a slave? Don’t let that worry you—but if you get a chance to be free, take it.
speaker: Narrator

text: And remember, if you were a slave when the Lord called you, you are now free in the Lord. And if you were free when the Lord called you, you are now a slave of Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: God paid a high price for you, so don’t be enslaved by the world.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each of you, dear brothers and sisters, should remain as you were when God first called you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now regarding your question about the young women who are not yet married. I do not have a command from the Lord for them. But the Lord in his mercy has given me wisdom that can be trusted, and I will share it with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because of the present crisis, I think it is best to remain as you are.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you have a wife, do not seek to end the marriage. If you do not have a wife, do not seek to get married.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you do get married, it is not a sin. And if a young woman gets married, it is not a sin. However, those who get married at this time will have troubles, and I am trying to spare you those problems.
speaker: Narrator

text: But let me say this, dear brothers and sisters: The time that remains is very short. So from now on, those with wives should not focus only on their marriage.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who weep or who rejoice or who buy things should not be absorbed by their weeping or their joy or their possessions.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who use the things of the world should not become attached to them. For this world as we know it will soon pass away.
speaker: Narrator

text: I want you to be free from the concerns of this life. An unmarried man can spend his time doing the Lord’s work and thinking how to please him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But a married man has to think about his earthly responsibilities and how to please his wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: His interests are divided. In the same way, a woman who is no longer married or has never been married can be devoted to the Lord and holy in body and in spirit. But a married woman has to think about her earthly responsibilities and how to please her husband.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am saying this for your benefit, not to place restrictions on you. I want you to do whatever will help you serve the Lord best, with as few distractions as possible.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if a man thinks that he’s treating his fiancée improperly and will inevitably give in to his passion, let him marry her as he wishes. It is not a sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if he has decided firmly not to marry and there is no urgency and he can control his passion, he does well not to marry.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the person who marries his fiancée does well, and the person who doesn’t marry does even better.
speaker: Narrator

text: A wife is bound to her husband as long as he lives. If her husband dies, she is free to marry anyone she wishes, but only if he loves the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: But in my opinion it would be better for her to stay single, and I think I am giving you counsel from God’s Spirit when I say this.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now regarding your question about food that has been offered to idols. Yes, we know that “we all have knowledge” about this issue. But while knowledge makes us feel important, it is love that strengthens the church.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone who claims to know all the answers doesn’t really know very much.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the person who loves God is the one whom God recognizes.
speaker: Narrator

text: So, what about eating meat that has been offered to idols? Well, we all know that an idol is not really a god and that there is only one God.
speaker: Narrator

text: There may be so-called gods both in heaven and on earth, and some people actually worship many gods and many lords.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But for us,
There is one God, the Father,
    by whom all things were created,
    and for whom we live.
And there is one Lord, Jesus Christ,
    through whom all things were created,
    and through whom we live.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, not all believers know this. Some are accustomed to thinking of idols as being real, so when they eat food that has been offered to idols, they think of it as the worship of real gods, and their weak consciences are violated.
speaker: Narrator

text: It’s true that we can’t win God’s approval by what we eat. We don’t lose anything if we don’t eat it, and we don’t gain anything if we do.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you must be careful so that your freedom does not cause others with a weaker conscience to stumble.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if others see you—with your “superior knowledge”—eating in the temple of an idol, won’t they be encouraged to violate their conscience by eating food that has been offered to an idol?
speaker: Narrator

text: So because of your superior knowledge, a weak believer for whom Christ died will be destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when you sin against other believers by encouraging them to do something they believe is wrong, you are sinning against Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: So if what I eat causes another believer to sin, I will never eat meat again as long as I live—for I don’t want to cause another believer to stumble.
speaker: Narrator

text: Am I not as free as anyone else? Am I not an apostle? Haven’t I seen Jesus our Lord with my own eyes? Isn’t it because of my work that you belong to the Lord?
speaker: Narrator

text: Even if others think I am not an apostle, I certainly am to you. You yourselves are proof that I am the Lord’s apostle.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is my answer to those who question my authority.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t we have the right to live in your homes and share your meals?
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t we have the right to bring a believing wife with us as the other apostles and the Lord’s brothers do, and as Peter does?
speaker: Narrator

text: Or is it only Barnabas and I who have to work to support ourselves?
speaker: Narrator

text: What soldier has to pay his own expenses? What farmer plants a vineyard and doesn’t have the right to eat some of its fruit? What shepherd cares for a flock of sheep and isn’t allowed to drink some of the milk?
speaker: Narrator

text: Am I expressing merely a human opinion, or does the law say the same thing?
speaker: Narrator

text: For the law of Moses says, “You must not muzzle an ox to keep it from eating as it treads out the grain.” Was God thinking only about oxen when he said this?
speaker: Narrator

text: Wasn’t he actually speaking to us? Yes, it was written for us, so that the one who plows and the one who threshes the grain might both expect a share of the harvest.
speaker: Narrator

text: Since we have planted spiritual seed among you, aren’t we entitled to a harvest of physical food and drink?
speaker: Narrator

text: If you support others who preach to you, shouldn’t we have an even greater right to be supported? But we have never used this right. We would rather put up with anything than be an obstacle to the Good News about Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t you realize that those who work in the temple get their meals from the offerings brought to the temple? And those who serve at the altar get a share of the sacrificial offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the same way, the Lord ordered that those who preach the Good News should be supported by those who benefit from it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet I have never used any of these rights. And I am not writing this to suggest that I want to start now. In fact, I would rather die than lose my right to boast about preaching without charge.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet preaching the Good News is not something I can boast about. I am compelled by God to do it. How terrible for me if I didn’t preach the Good News!
speaker: Narrator

text: If I were doing this on my own initiative, I would deserve payment. But I have no choice, for God has given me this sacred trust.
speaker: Narrator

text: What then is my pay? It is the opportunity to preach the Good News without charging anyone. That’s why I never demand my rights when I preach the Good News.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even though I am a free man with no master, I have become a slave to all people to bring many to Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: When I was with the Jews, I lived like a Jew to bring the Jews to Christ. When I was with those who follow the Jewish law, I too lived under that law. Even though I am not subject to the law, I did this so I could bring to Christ those who are under the law.
speaker: Narrator

text: When I am with the Gentiles who do not follow the Jewish law, I too live apart from that law so I can bring them to Christ. But I do not ignore the law of God; I obey the law of Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: When I am with those who are weak, I share their weakness, for I want to bring the weak to Christ. Yes, I try to find common ground with everyone, doing everything I can to save some.
speaker: Narrator

text: I do everything to spread the Good News and share in its blessings.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t you realize that in a race everyone runs, but only one person gets the prize? So run to win!
speaker: Narrator

text: All athletes are disciplined in their training. They do it to win a prize that will fade away, but we do it for an eternal prize.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I run with purpose in every step. I am not just shadowboxing.
speaker: Narrator

text: I discipline my body like an athlete, training it to do what it should. Otherwise, I fear that after preaching to others I myself might be disqualified.
speaker: Narrator

text: I don’t want you to forget, dear brothers and sisters, about our ancestors in the wilderness long ago. All of them were guided by a cloud that moved ahead of them, and all of them walked through the sea on dry ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the cloud and in the sea, all of them were baptized as followers of Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: All of them ate the same spiritual food,
speaker: Narrator

text: and all of them drank the same spiritual water. For they drank from the spiritual rock that traveled with them, and that rock was Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet God was not pleased with most of them, and their bodies were scattered in the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text: These things happened as a warning to us, so that we would not crave evil things as they did,
speaker: Narrator

text: or worship idols as some of them did. As the Scriptures say, “The people celebrated with feasting and drinking, and they indulged in pagan revelry.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And we must not engage in sexual immorality as some of them did, causing 23,000 of them to die in one day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nor should we put Christ to the test, as some of them did and then died from snakebites.
speaker: Narrator

text: And don’t grumble as some of them did, and then were destroyed by the angel of death.
speaker: Narrator

text: These things happened to them as examples for us. They were written down to warn us who live at the end of the age.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you think you are standing strong, be careful not to fall.
speaker: Narrator

text: The temptations in your life are no different from what others experience. And God is faithful. He will not allow the temptation to be more than you can stand. When you are tempted, he will show you a way out so that you can endure.
speaker: Narrator

text: So, my dear friends, flee from the worship of idols.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are reasonable people. Decide for yourselves if what I am saying is true.
speaker: Narrator

text: When we bless the cup at the Lord’s Table, aren’t we sharing in the blood of Christ? And when we break the bread, aren’t we sharing in the body of Christ?
speaker: Narrator

text: And though we are many, we all eat from one loaf of bread, showing that we are one body.
speaker: Narrator

text: Think about the people of Israel. Weren’t they united by eating the sacrifices at the altar?
speaker: Narrator

text: What am I trying to say? Am I saying that food offered to idols has some significance, or that idols are real gods?
speaker: Narrator

text: No, not at all. I am saying that these sacrifices are offered to demons, not to God. And I don’t want you to participate with demons.
speaker: Narrator

text: You cannot drink from the cup of the Lord and from the cup of demons, too. You cannot eat at the Lord’s Table and at the table of demons, too.
speaker: Narrator

text: What? Do we dare to rouse the Lord’s jealousy? Do you think we are stronger than he is?
speaker: Narrator

text: You say, “I am allowed to do anything”—but not everything is good for you. You say, “I am allowed to do anything”—but not everything is beneficial.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t be concerned for your own good but for the good of others.
speaker: Narrator

text: So you may eat any meat that is sold in the marketplace without raising questions of conscience.
speaker: Narrator

text: For “the earth is the Lord’s, and everything in it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: If someone who isn’t a believer asks you home for dinner, accept the invitation if you want to. Eat whatever is offered to you without raising questions of conscience.
speaker: Narrator

text: (But suppose someone tells you, “This meat was offered to an idol.” Don’t eat it, out of consideration for the conscience of the one who told you.
speaker: Narrator

text: It might not be a matter of conscience for you, but it is for the other person.) For why should my freedom be limited by what someone else thinks?
speaker: Narrator

text: If I can thank God for the food and enjoy it, why should I be condemned for eating it?
speaker: Narrator

text: So whether you eat or drink, or whatever you do, do it all for the glory of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t give offense to Jews or Gentiles or the church of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: I, too, try to please everyone in everything I do. I don’t just do what is best for me; I do what is best for others so that many may be saved.
speaker: Narrator

text: And you should imitate me, just as I imitate Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am so glad that you always keep me in your thoughts, and that you are following the teachings I passed on to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But there is one thing I want you to know: The head of every man is Christ, the head of woman is man, and the head of Christ is God.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man dishonors his head if he covers his head while praying or prophesying.
speaker: Narrator

text: But a woman dishonors her head if she prays or prophesies without a covering on her head, for this is the same as shaving her head.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yes, if she refuses to wear a head covering, she should cut off all her hair! But since it is shameful for a woman to have her hair cut or her head shaved, she should wear a covering.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man should not wear anything on his head when worshiping, for man is made in God’s image and reflects God’s glory. And woman reflects man’s glory.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the first man didn’t come from woman, but the first woman came from man.
speaker: Narrator

text: And man was not made for woman, but woman was made for man.
speaker: Narrator

text: For this reason, and because the angels are watching, a woman should wear a covering on her head to show she is under authority.
speaker: Narrator

text: But among the Lord’s people, women are not independent of men, and men are not independent of women.
speaker: Narrator

text: For although the first woman came from man, every other man was born from a woman, and everything comes from God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Judge for yourselves. Is it right for a woman to pray to God in public without covering her head?
speaker: Narrator

text: Isn’t it obvious that it’s disgraceful for a man to have long hair?
speaker: Narrator

text: And isn’t long hair a woman’s pride and joy? For it has been given to her as a covering.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if anyone wants to argue about this, I simply say that we have no other custom than this, and neither do God’s other churches.
speaker: Narrator

text: But in the following instructions, I cannot praise you. For it sounds as if more harm than good is done when you meet together.
speaker: Narrator

text: First, I hear that there are divisions among you when you meet as a church, and to some extent I believe it.
speaker: Narrator

text: But, of course, there must be divisions among you so that you who have God’s approval will be recognized!
speaker: Narrator

text: When you meet together, you are not really interested in the Lord’s Supper.
speaker: Narrator

text: For some of you hurry to eat your own meal without sharing with others. As a result, some go hungry while others get drunk.
speaker: Narrator

text: What? Don’t you have your own homes for eating and drinking? Or do you really want to disgrace God’s church and shame the poor? What am I supposed to say? Do you want me to praise you? Well, I certainly will not praise you for this!
speaker: Narrator

text: For I pass on to you what I received from the Lord himself. On the night when he was betrayed, the Lord Jesus took some bread
speaker: Narrator

text: and gave thanks to God for it. Then he broke it in pieces and said, “This is my body, which is given for you. Do this in remembrance of me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In the same way, he took the cup of wine after supper, saying, “This cup is the new covenant between God and his people—an agreement confirmed with my blood. Do this in remembrance of me as often as you drink it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: For every time you eat this bread and drink this cup, you are announcing the Lord’s death until he comes again.
speaker: Narrator

text: So anyone who eats this bread or drinks this cup of the Lord unworthily is guilty of sinning against the body and blood of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: That is why you should examine yourself before eating the bread and drinking the cup.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if you eat the bread or drink the cup without honoring the body of Christ, you are eating and drinking God’s judgment upon yourself.
speaker: Narrator

text: That is why many of you are weak and sick and some have even died.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if we would examine ourselves, we would not be judged by God in this way.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet when we are judged by the Lord, we are being disciplined so that we will not be condemned along with the world.
speaker: Narrator

text: So, my dear brothers and sisters, when you gather for the Lord’s Supper, wait for each other.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you are really hungry, eat at home so you won’t bring judgment upon yourselves when you meet together. I’ll give you instructions about the other matters after I arrive.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, dear brothers and sisters, regarding your question about the special abilities the Spirit gives us. I don’t want you to misunderstand this.
speaker: Narrator

text: You know that when you were still pagans, you were led astray and swept along in worshiping speechless idols.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I want you to know that no one speaking by the Spirit of God will curse Jesus, and no one can say Jesus is Lord, except by the Holy Spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text: There are different kinds of spiritual gifts, but the same Spirit is the source of them all.
speaker: Narrator

text: There are different kinds of service, but we serve the same Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: God works in different ways, but it is the same God who does the work in all of us.
speaker: Narrator

text: A spiritual gift is given to each of us so we can help each other.
speaker: Narrator

text: To one person the Spirit gives the ability to give wise advice; to another the same Spirit gives a message of special knowledge.
speaker: Narrator

text: The same Spirit gives great faith to another, and to someone else the one Spirit gives the gift of healing.
speaker: Narrator

text: He gives one person the power to perform miracles, and another the ability to prophesy. He gives someone else the ability to discern whether a message is from the Spirit of God or from another spirit. Still another person is given the ability to speak in unknown languages, while another is given the ability to interpret what is being said.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is the one and only Spirit who distributes all these gifts. He alone decides which gift each person should have.
speaker: Narrator

text: The human body has many parts, but the many parts make up one whole body. So it is with the body of Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some of us are Jews, some are Gentiles, some are slaves, and some are free. But we have all been baptized into one body by one Spirit, and we all share the same Spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yes, the body has many different parts, not just one part.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the foot says, “I am not a part of the body because I am not a hand,” that does not make it any less a part of the body.
speaker: Narrator

text: And if the ear says, “I am not part of the body because I am not an eye,” would that make it any less a part of the body?
speaker: Narrator

text: If the whole body were an eye, how would you hear? Or if your whole body were an ear, how would you smell anything?
speaker: Narrator

text: But our bodies have many parts, and God has put each part just where he wants it.
speaker: Narrator

text: How strange a body would be if it had only one part!
speaker: Narrator

text: Yes, there are many parts, but only one body.
speaker: Narrator

text: The eye can never say to the hand, “I don’t need you.” The head can’t say to the feet, “I don’t need you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In fact, some parts of the body that seem weakest and least important are actually the most necessary.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the parts we regard as less honorable are those we clothe with the greatest care. So we carefully protect those parts that should not be seen,
speaker: Narrator

text: while the more honorable parts do not require this special care. So God has put the body together such that extra honor and care are given to those parts that have less dignity.
speaker: Narrator

text: This makes for harmony among the members, so that all the members care for each other.
speaker: Narrator

text: If one part suffers, all the parts suffer with it, and if one part is honored, all the parts are glad.
speaker: Narrator

text: All of you together are Christ’s body, and each of you is a part of it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Here are some of the parts God has appointed for the church:
first are apostles,
second are prophets,
third are teachers,
then those who do miracles,
those who have the gift of healing,
those who can help others,
those who have the gift of leadership,
those who speak in unknown languages.
speaker: Narrator

text: Are we all apostles? Are we all prophets? Are we all teachers? Do we all have the power to do miracles?
speaker: Narrator

text: Do we all have the gift of healing? Do we all have the ability to speak in unknown languages? Do we all have the ability to interpret unknown languages? Of course not!
speaker: Narrator

text:
So you should earnestly desire the most helpful gifts.
But now let me show you a way of life that is best of all.
speaker: Narrator

text: If I could speak all the languages of earth and of angels, but didn’t love others, I would only be a noisy gong or a clanging cymbal.
speaker: Narrator

text: If I had the gift of prophecy, and if I understood all of God’s secret plans and possessed all knowledge, and if I had such faith that I could move mountains, but didn’t love others, I would be nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text: If I gave everything I have to the poor and even sacrificed my body, I could boast about it; but if I didn’t love others, I would have gained nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Love is patient and kind. Love is not jealous or boastful or proud
speaker: Narrator

text: or rude. It does not demand its own way. It is not irritable, and it keeps no record of being wronged.
speaker: Narrator

text: It does not rejoice about injustice but rejoices whenever the truth wins out.
speaker: Narrator

text: Love never gives up, never loses faith, is always hopeful, and endures through every circumstance.
speaker: Narrator

text: Prophecy and speaking in unknown languages and special knowledge will become useless. But love will last forever!
speaker: Narrator

text: Now our knowledge is partial and incomplete, and even the gift of prophecy reveals only part of the whole picture!
speaker: Narrator

text: But when the time of perfection comes, these partial things will become useless.
speaker: Narrator

text: When I was a child, I spoke and thought and reasoned as a child. But when I grew up, I put away childish things.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now we see things imperfectly, like puzzling reflections in a mirror, but then we will see everything with perfect clarity. All that I know now is partial and incomplete, but then I will know everything completely, just as God now knows me completely.
speaker: Narrator

text: Three things will last forever—faith, hope, and love—and the greatest of these is love.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let love be your highest goal! But you should also desire the special abilities the Spirit gives—especially the ability to prophesy.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if you have the ability to speak in tongues, you will be talking only to God, since people won’t be able to understand you. You will be speaking by the power of the Spirit, but it will all be mysterious.
speaker: Narrator

text: But one who prophesies strengthens others, encourages them, and comforts them.
speaker: Narrator

text: A person who speaks in tongues is strengthened personally, but one who speaks a word of prophecy strengthens the entire church.
speaker: Narrator

text: I wish you could all speak in tongues, but even more I wish you could all prophesy. For prophecy is greater than speaking in tongues, unless someone interprets what you are saying so that the whole church will be strengthened.
speaker: Narrator

text: Dear brothers and sisters, if I should come to you speaking in an unknown language, how would that help you? But if I bring you a revelation or some special knowledge or prophecy or teaching, that will be helpful.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even lifeless instruments like the flute or the harp must play the notes clearly, or no one will recognize the melody.
speaker: Narrator

text: And if the bugler doesn’t sound a clear call, how will the soldiers know they are being called to battle?
speaker: Narrator

text: It’s the same for you. If you speak to people in words they don’t understand, how will they know what you are saying? You might as well be talking into empty space.
speaker: Narrator

text: There are many different languages in the world, and every language has meaning.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if I don’t understand a language, I will be a foreigner to someone who speaks it, and the one who speaks it will be a foreigner to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the same is true for you. Since you are so eager to have the special abilities the Spirit gives, seek those that will strengthen the whole church.
speaker: Narrator

text: So anyone who speaks in tongues should pray also for the ability to interpret what has been said.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if I pray in tongues, my spirit is praying, but I don’t understand what I am saying.
speaker: Narrator

text: Well then, what shall I do? I will pray in the spirit, and I will also pray in words I understand. I will sing in the spirit, and I will also sing in words I understand.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if you praise God only in the spirit, how can those who don’t understand you praise God along with you? How can they join you in giving thanks when they don’t understand what you are saying?
speaker: Narrator

text: You will be giving thanks very well, but it won’t strengthen the people who hear you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I thank God that I speak in tongues more than any of you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But in a church meeting I would rather speak five understandable words to help others than ten thousand words in an unknown language.
speaker: Narrator

text: Dear brothers and sisters, don’t be childish in your understanding of these things. Be innocent as babies when it comes to evil, but be mature in understanding matters of this kind.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is written in the Scriptures:
“I will speak to my own people
    through strange languages
    and through the lips of foreigners.
But even then, they will not listen to me,”
    says the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: So you see that speaking in tongues is a sign, not for believers, but for unbelievers. Prophecy, however, is for the benefit of believers, not unbelievers.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even so, if unbelievers or people who don’t understand these things come into your church meeting and hear everyone speaking in an unknown language, they will think you are crazy.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if all of you are prophesying, and unbelievers or people who don’t understand these things come into your meeting, they will be convicted of sin and judged by what you say.
speaker: Narrator

text: As they listen, their secret thoughts will be exposed, and they will fall to their knees and worship God, declaring, “God is truly here among you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Well, my brothers and sisters, let’s summarize. When you meet together, one will sing, another will teach, another will tell some special revelation God has given, one will speak in tongues, and another will interpret what is said. But everything that is done must strengthen all of you.
speaker: Narrator

text: No more than two or three should speak in tongues. They must speak one at a time, and someone must interpret what they say.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if no one is present who can interpret, they must be silent in your church meeting and speak in tongues to God privately.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let two or three people prophesy, and let the others evaluate what is said.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if someone is prophesying and another person receives a revelation from the Lord, the one who is speaking must stop.
speaker: Narrator

text: In this way, all who prophesy will have a turn to speak, one after the other, so that everyone will learn and be encouraged.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember that people who prophesy are in control of their spirit and can take turns.
speaker: Narrator

text: For God is not a God of disorder but of peace, as in all the meetings of God’s holy people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Women should be silent during the church meetings. It is not proper for them to speak. They should be submissive, just as the law says.
speaker: Narrator

text: If they have any questions, they should ask their husbands at home, for it is improper for women to speak in church meetings.
speaker: Narrator

text: Or do you think God’s word originated with you Corinthians? Are you the only ones to whom it was given?
speaker: Narrator

text: If you claim to be a prophet or think you are spiritual, you should recognize that what I am saying is a command from the Lord himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you do not recognize this, you yourself will not be recognized.
speaker: Narrator

text: So, my dear brothers and sisters, be eager to prophesy, and don’t forbid speaking in tongues.
speaker: Narrator

text: But be sure that everything is done properly and in order.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let me now remind you, dear brothers and sisters, of the Good News I preached to you before. You welcomed it then, and you still stand firm in it.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is this Good News that saves you if you continue to believe the message I told you—unless, of course, you believed something that was never true in the first place.
speaker: Narrator

text: I passed on to you what was most important and what had also been passed on to me. Christ died for our sins, just as the Scriptures said.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was buried, and he was raised from the dead on the third day, just as the Scriptures said.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was seen by Peter and then by the Twelve.
speaker: Narrator

text: After that, he was seen by more than 500 of his followers at one time, most of whom are still alive, though some have died.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he was seen by James and later by all the apostles.
speaker: Narrator

text: Last of all, as though I had been born at the wrong time, I also saw him.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I am the least of all the apostles. In fact, I’m not even worthy to be called an apostle after the way I persecuted God’s church.
speaker: Narrator

text: But whatever I am now, it is all because God poured out his special favor on me—and not without results. For I have worked harder than any of the other apostles; yet it was not I but God who was working through me by his grace.
speaker: Narrator

text: So it makes no difference whether I preach or they preach, for we all preach the same message you have already believed.
speaker: Narrator

text: But tell me this—since we preach that Christ rose from the dead, why are some of you saying there will be no resurrection of the dead?
speaker: Narrator

text: For if there is no resurrection of the dead, then Christ has not been raised either.
speaker: Narrator

text: And if Christ has not been raised, then all our preaching is useless, and your faith is useless.
speaker: Narrator

text: And we apostles would all be lying about God—for we have said that God raised Christ from the grave. But that can’t be true if there is no resurrection of the dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: And if there is no resurrection of the dead, then Christ has not been raised.
speaker: Narrator

text: And if Christ has not been raised, then your faith is useless and you are still guilty of your sins.
speaker: Narrator

text: In that case, all who have died believing in Christ are lost!
speaker: Narrator

text: And if our hope in Christ is only for this life, we are more to be pitied than anyone in the world.
speaker: Narrator

text: But in fact, Christ has been raised from the dead. He is the first of a great harvest of all who have died.
speaker: Narrator

text: So you see, just as death came into the world through a man, now the resurrection from the dead has begun through another man.
speaker: Narrator

text: Just as everyone dies because we all belong to Adam, everyone who belongs to Christ will be given new life.
speaker: Narrator

text: But there is an order to this resurrection: Christ was raised as the first of the harvest; then all who belong to Christ will be raised when he comes back.
speaker: Narrator

text: After that the end will come, when he will turn the Kingdom over to God the Father, having destroyed every ruler and authority and power.
speaker: Narrator

text: For Christ must reign until he humbles all his enemies beneath his feet.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the last enemy to be destroyed is death.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Scriptures say, “God has put all things under his authority.” (Of course, when it says “all things are under his authority,” that does not include God himself, who gave Christ his authority.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Then, when all things are under his authority, the Son will put himself under God’s authority, so that God, who gave his Son authority over all things, will be utterly supreme over everything everywhere.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the dead will not be raised, what point is there in people being baptized for those who are dead? Why do it unless the dead will someday rise again?
speaker: Narrator

text: And why should we ourselves risk our lives hour by hour?
speaker: Narrator

text: For I swear, dear brothers and sisters, that I face death daily. This is as certain as my pride in what Christ Jesus our Lord has done in you.
speaker: Narrator

text: And what value was there in fighting wild beasts—those people of Ephesus—if there will be no resurrection from the dead? And if there is no resurrection, “Let’s feast and drink, for tomorrow we die!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t be fooled by those who say such things, for “bad company corrupts good character.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Think carefully about what is right, and stop sinning. For to your shame I say that some of you don’t know God at all.
speaker: Narrator

text: But someone may ask, “How will the dead be raised? What kind of bodies will they have?”
speaker: Narrator

text: What a foolish question! When you put a seed into the ground, it doesn’t grow into a plant unless it dies first.
speaker: Narrator

text: And what you put in the ground is not the plant that will grow, but only a bare seed of wheat or whatever you are planting.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God gives it the new body he wants it to have. A different plant grows from each kind of seed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Similarly there are different kinds of flesh—one kind for humans, another for animals, another for birds, and another for fish.
speaker: Narrator

text: There are also bodies in the heavens and bodies on the earth. The glory of the heavenly bodies is different from the glory of the earthly bodies.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sun has one kind of glory, while the moon and stars each have another kind. And even the stars differ from each other in their glory.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is the same way with the resurrection of the dead. Our earthly bodies are planted in the ground when we die, but they will be raised to live forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: Our bodies are buried in brokenness, but they will be raised in glory. They are buried in weakness, but they will be raised in strength.
speaker: Narrator

text: They are buried as natural human bodies, but they will be raised as spiritual bodies. For just as there are natural bodies, there are also spiritual bodies.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Scriptures tell us, “The first man, Adam, became a living person.” But the last Adam—that is, Christ—is a life-giving Spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text: What comes first is the natural body, then the spiritual body comes later.
speaker: Narrator

text: Adam, the first man, was made from the dust of the earth, while Christ, the second man, came from heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: Earthly people are like the earthly man, and heavenly people are like the heavenly man.
speaker: Narrator

text: Just as we are now like the earthly man, we will someday be like the heavenly man.
speaker: Narrator

text: What I am saying, dear brothers and sisters, is that our physical bodies cannot inherit the Kingdom of God. These dying bodies cannot inherit what will last forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: But let me reveal to you a wonderful secret. We will not all die, but we will all be transformed!
speaker: Narrator

text: It will happen in a moment, in the blink of an eye, when the last trumpet is blown. For when the trumpet sounds, those who have died will be raised to live forever. And we who are living will also be transformed.
speaker: Narrator

text: For our dying bodies must be transformed into bodies that will never die; our mortal bodies must be transformed into immortal bodies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then, when our dying bodies have been transformed into bodies that will never die, this Scripture will be fulfilled:
“Death is swallowed up in victory.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O death, where is your victory?
    O death, where is your sting?”
speaker: Narrator

text: For sin is the sting that results in death, and the law gives sin its power.
speaker: Narrator

text: But thank God! He gives us victory over sin and death through our Lord Jesus Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: So, my dear brothers and sisters, be strong and immovable. Always work enthusiastically for the Lord, for you know that nothing you do for the Lord is ever useless.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now regarding your question about the money being collected for God’s people in Jerusalem. You should follow the same procedure I gave to the churches in Galatia.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the first day of each week, you should each put aside a portion of the money you have earned. Don’t wait until I get there and then try to collect it all at once.
speaker: Narrator

text: When I come, I will write letters of recommendation for the messengers you choose to deliver your gift to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: And if it seems appropriate for me to go along, they can travel with me.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am coming to visit you after I have been to Macedonia, for I am planning to travel through Macedonia.
speaker: Narrator

text: Perhaps I will stay awhile with you, possibly all winter, and then you can send me on my way to my next destination.
speaker: Narrator

text: This time I don’t want to make just a short visit and then go right on. I want to come and stay awhile, if the Lord will let me.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the meantime, I will be staying here at Ephesus until the Festival of Pentecost.
speaker: Narrator

text: There is a wide-open door for a great work here, although many oppose me.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Timothy comes, don’t intimidate him. He is doing the Lord’s work, just as I am.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t let anyone treat him with contempt. Send him on his way with your blessing when he returns to me. I expect him to come with the other believers.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now about our brother Apollos—I urged him to visit you with the other believers, but he was not willing to go right now. He will see you later when he has the opportunity.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be on guard. Stand firm in the faith. Be courageous. Be strong.
speaker: Narrator

text: And do everything with love.
speaker: Narrator

text: You know that Stephanas and his household were the first of the harvest of believers in Greece, and they are spending their lives in service to God’s people. I urge you, dear brothers and sisters,
speaker: Narrator

text: to submit to them and others like them who serve with such devotion.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am very glad that Stephanas, Fortunatus, and Achaicus have come here. They have been providing the help you weren’t here to give me.
speaker: Narrator

text: They have been a wonderful encouragement to me, as they have been to you. You must show your appreciation to all who serve so well.
speaker: Narrator

text: The churches here in the province of Asia send greetings in the Lord, as do Aquila and Priscilla and all the others who gather in their home for church meetings.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the brothers and sisters here send greetings to you. Greet each other with a sacred kiss.
speaker: Narrator

text: HERE IS MY GREETING IN MY OWN HANDWRITING—PAUL.
speaker: Narrator

text: If anyone does not love the Lord, that person is cursed. Our Lord, come!
speaker: Narrator

text: May the grace of the Lord Jesus be with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: My love to all of you in Christ Jesus.
speaker: Narrator
